Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 46263 
Regional—Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (R-PATA) 
September 2012 
 
 
 
Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation: 
Midterm Review of the Transport and Trade 
Facilitation Strategy and Implementation Action Plan 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC)  Transport  and  Trade 
Facilitation Strategy (the strategy)—developed with Asian Development Bank (ADB) technical 
assistance (TA)1 and endorsed by CAREC countries in 20072—aims to support CAREC’s goal 
of development through cooperation by upgrading, through construction and rehabilitation, key 
corridors  across  the  region  and  simplifying  and  harmonizing  the  regulations  that  govern  
cross-border trade in the region. The strategy entails a time-bound implementation action plan 
that was endorsed by CAREC countries in 2008.3 The action plan specifies the key results, 
prioritizes investments and TA projects, and provides measurable performance indicators. 
 
2.  The strategy stipulates a midterm review to be conducted during 2013–2014 to optimize 
its implementation in the remaining period. The new 10-year (2011–2020) strategic framework 
for CAREC (CAREC 2020), which was endorsed by CAREC countries in November 2011, also 
calls for a midterm review of the strategy and implementation action plan. In addition, the mid-
term review of the strategy and implementation action plan is needed to specify the CAREC 
corridors for the two new participating countries: Pakistan and Turkmenistan. At the 11th CAREC 
Transport Sector Coordinating Committee Meeting held in June 2012 in Manila, Philippines, the 
CAREC governments concurred to the proposed TA’s impact, outcome, outputs, cost, financing 
and  implementation  arrangements,  and  consultant’s  terms  of  reference.4 The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The strategy and implementation action plan focus on (i) about 24,000 kilometers (km) of 
roads,5 20,000 km of railways, and 28 border crossing points along CAREC corridors; (ii) three 
ports (Aktau in Kazakhstan, Turkmenbashi in Turkmenistan, and Baku in Azerbaijan) and a 
shipping route (400 km between Aktau and Baku); and (iii) 41 airports with international air 
service. The strategy specifies the key results to be achieved on (i) about 75% of the CAREC 
corridors improved by 2012 and 100% by 2017, compared with 64% in 2007; (ii) increased 
transit trade volume via CAREC corridors to 2% of trade between Europe and East Asia by 
2012 and 5% by 2017, from less than 1% (about 34 million tons) in 2005; (iii) increased intra-
regional trade volume by 25% by 2012 and by 50% by 2017, from the 2005 level (about 32 
million tons); (iv) reduced time for border crossing along CAREC corridors by 50% by 2012 and 
by an additional 30% by 2017, compared with 2007; and (v) effective functioning of the national 
joint transport and trade facilitation committee or a similar organization in each CAREC country 
for managing the CAREC corridors by 2012. 
 
4.  The strategy is now halfway through its implementation period, with progress having 
been made in constructing and rehabilitating transport infrastructure along the corridors. As of 
end-2011, the cumulative total of the highways built stood at 3,512 km; this means that 79% of 
the total length of CAREC corridors is in good conditions. This exceeds the 2011 target of

71.5%.6 Meanwhile, cross-border transit agreements and the modernization of border crossing 
facilities  have  contributed  to  trade  increases  within  CAREC  and  with  neighboring  regions.  
These  achievements,  together  with  significant  global  and  regional  trade  developments  
(see  paragraph  5),  have  implications  on  the  strategy  and  implementation  action  plan. 
Accordingly, there will be a need to review the progress of the strategy and implementation 
action  plan  during  2013–2014  to  ensure  that  it  remains  relevant  and  effective  during  the 
remaining implementation period. 
 
5.  The review of the strategy and implementation action plan will be conducted amid three 
major global and regional developments: (i) globalization has resulted in profound changes in 
global production structures and supply chains, (ii) all CAREC countries have achieved differing 
degrees of economic growth since 2007, and (iii) Pakistan and Turkmenistan joined the CAREC 
Program in November 2010. These developments are posing three challenges to the strategy 
and implementation action plan: (i) globalization is likely to  alter supply chains in CAREC 
countries,  affecting their  trade and traffic flows  and  increasing the  importance  of  logistics;  
(ii) participation of Pakistan and Turkmenistan in CAREC necessitates an expansion of the 
regional transport network to increase the competitiveness of CAREC countries in response to 
new global and regional supply chains; and (iii) sustained regional transport cooperation among 
CAREC countries depends on other regional cooperation programs (e.g., the Trans-European 
networks of the European Union and the Greater Mekong Subregion) and on fair distribution of 
costs and benefits of the regional transport network in CAREC countries. The TA will address 
these challenges by (i) refining the strategy and implementation action plan in the context of 
major  global  and  regional  developments;  (ii)  specifying  the  corridors  in  Pakistan  and 
Turkmenistan; and (iii) recommending realignment of the existing CAREC corridors, if needed. 
Specifically, the review of the strategy and implementation action plan will focus on the issues 
described in paragraphs 6–11. 
 
6.  Connectivity. Improvement of the existing six CAREC corridors has yet to be completed, 
and changes in the supply chain have resulted in new traffic patterns and possible new corridors 
for  connectivity.  Moreover,  the  participation  of  Pakistan  and  Turkmenistan  in  CAREC  in 
November 2010 highlights the need to strengthen connectivity between these two countries and 
other CAREC countries. The TA will take these factors into account to assess the effectiveness 
of the CAREC corridors and identify new corridors. It will also identify the major corridors in 
Pakistan and Turkmenistan that connect to neighboring CAREC countries, South Asia, and 
other regions. Using trade and traffic forecasts, the TA will identify optimal regional transport 
corridors and propose ways to develop and realign those corridors. 
 
7.  Cross-border  movement.  Cross-border  facilitation  has  become  an  integral  part  of 
transport cooperation under CAREC, requiring cooperative efforts from all agencies working at 
borders,  including  immigration  control,  customs,  and  inspection  and  quarantine  agencies. 
Together with international development partners (e.g., the United Nations Economic and Social 
Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific,  the  World  Customs  Organization,  the  World  Trade 
Organization), ADB has supported the efforts of CAREC countries to improve border facilities, 
strengthen border officers’ capacities, and develop cross-border agreements. A cross-border 
transport agreement was signed by the Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan in December 2010, and 
was ratified by Tajikistan in March 2011 and the Kyrgyz Republic in June 2011. Afghanistan has 
also expressed its intention to accede to the cross-border transport agreement. Despite these 
efforts,  cross-border  movements  among  CAREC  countries  remain  inefficient  due  to

Manila.

3 
 
non-harmonized policies and procedures, as well as inadequate border facilities. The TA will 
examine these cross-border obstacles and formulate the actions to eliminate them. 
 
8.  Integrated multimodal transport system. The CAREC transport network comprises 
railways,  roads,  civil  aviation,  and  waterways.  An  integrated  multimodal  regional  transport 
system is essential to reduce transport costs and foster trade, investment, and other economic 
activities. Despite some progress, an integrated multimodal transport system has yet to be fully 
operational in CAREC countries. The TA will adopt an integrated multimodal transport approach 
by assessing multimodal transport infrastructure, harmonizing regulations and procedures set 
by  modal  agencies,  and  tackling  multimodal  logistic  issues  through cooperation  among  all 
transport modal agencies. 
 
9.  Road  maintenance.  Road  maintenance  remains  a  daunting  challenge  in  CAREC 
countries  because  of  growing  vehicle  axle  overloading,  weak  enforcement  of  regulations, 
inadequate funding, and ineffective management and practices. These factors threaten the 
improved sections of the CAREC corridors, reducing their economic and social benefits and 
causing concern about road safety. The TA will assess the current road maintenance status of 
CAREC corridors and propose ways for improvement. 
 
10.  Road safety. Road safety has become a global issue as nearly 1.3 million people are 
killed and as many as 50 million are injured or disabled each year due to road crashes.  
The CAREC countries are no exception; road accidents on CAREC corridors have increased 
since 2007. The major causes of the problem include the rapid growth in motorized vehicles, 
inadequate road safety features on road corridors, weak enforcement of traffic regulations, 
insufficient training of drivers, and limited public awareness. Lack of coordination on road safety 
among various relevant government agencies also contributes to the problem. The growing 
number of road accidents result in significant human and economic losses, and have a poverty 
impact as many victims’ families suffer decreased income and become vulnerable. The TA will 
assess  the  road  safety  situation  on  CAREC  corridors  and  identify  effective  road  safety 
improvement measures for implementation. 
 
11.  Environment  and  social  safeguards.  Development  of  CAREC  corridors  through 
construction and rehabilitation is associated with several environmental and social safeguard 
issues.  The  major  environmental  and  social  issues  involved  include  pollution,  spread  of 
HIV/AIDS and infectious diseases, and human and drug trafficking. These issues need to be 
tackled to ensure the sustainability of the CAREC’s regional transport network. The TA will 
assess these environmental and social issues and propose measurers to mitigate and minimize 
their impacts. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The TA will contribute to expanded trade among CAREC countries and between CAREC 
countries and the rest of the world. The outcome of the TA will be the endorsement and 
adoption of the updated CAREC Transport and Trade Facilitation Strategy by CAREC countries. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA will be implemented in two phases. Phase 1 will conduct a comprehensive  
stock-take analysis of the implementation progress of the strategy and implementation action

4 
 
plan. The stock-take will assess progress on (i) regional transport networks, infrastructure, and 
services;  (ii)  major  cross-border  facilities  and  arrangements;  (iii)  policies,  legislation,  and 
regulations relating to regional transport; (iv) transport financing and financial management 
capacity; (v) institutional and human resource capacity in the transport sector; (vi) public–private 
partnerships in regional transport. The stock-take will also ascertain the demand for regional 
and transit transport and shares of transport modes. Based on the outcome of phase 1, the 
strategy and implementation action plan will be updated in phase 2, which should (i) identify 
ways to respond to the long-term challenges for CAREC regional transport cooperation and 
development, including the impact of new global supply chains and production structures on 
CAREC regional trade and traffic flows; (ii) forecast demand for regional and transit trade and 
transport; (iii) set strategic priorities for regional transport development through cooperation for 
2013–2017, including safety and maintenance strategies; (iv) identify major regional transport 
corridors based on trade flow analysis; (v) specify the role of each transport mode in the 
regional transport network; (vi) identify further transport policy and institutional reforms needed 
to  promote  regional  traffic;  (vii)  propose  methods  to  facilitate  the  harmonization  of  trade 
facilitation  policies  in  CAREC  countries;  (viii)  propose  measures  to  enhance  public–private 
partnerships for regional transport development; (ix) propose a capacity building framework;  
(x) develop an action plan for implementation; (xi) consider CAREC 2020 and the experience of 
other, more advanced regional initiatives (e.g., the trans-European networks of the European 
Union and the Greater Mekong Subregion); (xii) produce updated CAREC corridors that include 
Pakistan and Turkmenistan, following the five criteria specified in the strategy; and (xiii) identify 
new priority projects and specify the resources required for implementing these projects. 
 
14.  The  TA  was  designed  in  consultation  with  stakeholders  and  endorsed  at  the  
10th CAREC Transport Sector Coordinating Committee Meeting held in Astana, Kazakhstan in 
October 2011, and at the 10th Ministerial Conference on CAREC held in Baku, Azerbaijan in 
November 2011; comments made at these meetings were incorporated into the TA design. 
During  TA  implementation,  stakeholder  consultation  will  continue  through  country-based 
meetings to discuss the draft report on the stock-take of the implementation progress of the 
strategy and implementation action plan, and the draft of the updated and refined strategy and 
implementation action plan. 
 
15.  Key TA activities will include (i) desk studies of existing documents, studies, and reports; 
(ii) data analysis; (iii) field surveys; and (iv) stakeholder consultations. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,500,000 equivalent, to be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–IV). The cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency,  with  its  Central  and  West  Asia  Department 
implementing the TA. The TA will be implemented over 12 months from November 2012, when 
the  procurement  of  the  consulting  firm  is  expected  to  be  finalized,  to  November  2013.  
The TA will be implemented in collaboration with ADB’s other relevant departments and resident 
missions in CAREC countries, development partners involved in the CAREC program, and 
relevant government agencies in CAREC countries.

5 
 
18.  The TA will require approximately 41 person-months of international consulting services. 
The team of international consultants will comprise the following experts: (i) transport planner, 
(ii)  macro  and  trade  economist,  (iii)  transport  economist,  (iv)  freight  transport  specialist,  
(v)  passenger  transport  specialist,  (vi)  governance  specialist,  (vii)  cross-border  and  trade 
facilitation  specialist,  (viii)  regional  cooperation  specialist,  (ix)  gender  specialist,  and  
(x)  environment  and  social  safeguards  specialist.  National  consultants  in  selected  CAREC 
countries may be engaged for up to 80 person-months to assist in the international consultants’ 
work. Individual consultants will be engaged for up to 24 person-months to coordinate the TA 
activities  at  ADB.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consultants  are  in  Appendix  3.  
The  consultants  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) using advance procurement, the quality- and 
cost-based selection method (with a quality-cost ratio of 90:10), and a full technical proposal. 
 
19.  Equipment budgeted under the TA consists of computers and small office equipment 
that will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended 
from time to time).7 Disbursements will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
20.  The  deliverables  of  the  TA  will  be  presented  for  respective  endorsements  at  the 
meetings of the CAREC Transport Sector Coordinating Committee and Customs Cooperation 
Committee, CAREC senior officials’ meetings, and CAREC ministerial conferences. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis 
for the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation: Midterm Review of the Transport and 
Trade Facilitation Strategy and Implementation Action Plan, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board. 
 
                                                
7  Upon TA completion, any equipment procured will be disposed of in accordance with ADB Project Administration 
Instruction 5.09 (Administering Grant-Financed Technical Assistance Projects, rev. January 2009), Section T. 
paragraph 68.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consultants’ Tasks 
 
1.  The consulting firm’s tasks will include, but will not be limited to: 
 
(i)  Undertaking a comprehensive stock-take of the progress achieved and results 
realized during the first half implementation (2008–2012) of the Central Asia 
Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC)  Transport  and  Trade  Facilitation 
Strategy and Implementation Action Plan. Based on the review, the consulting 
firm will prepare a report, which will be presented at a regional consultative 
workshop. Based on the comments received from workshop participants and 
CAREC governments, the consulting firm will finalize the report on the review of 
the strategy and implementation action plan. 
 
(ii)  Identifying the long-term challenges for CAREC regional transport cooperation 
and  development,  taking  into  account  the  (a)  global  and  regional  context,  
(b) national development strategies in CAREC countries, (c) experience of the 
CAREC program to date, and (d) other regional transport cooperation initiatives. 
The consulting firm will also assess the responses of CAREC countries and the 
CAREC program to these challenges. 
 
(iii)  Assessing the impact of new global supply chains and production structures on 
CAREC regional trade and traffic flows, identifying ongoing efforts in CAREC 
countries to adjust to these changes, and recommending best ways to respond to 
the impact. 
 
(iv)  Assessing the role of the transport sector in developing economic corridors and 
proposing  ways  to  maximize  transport’s  contribution  to  economic  corridor 
development under CAREC, including measures to transform transport corridors 
into economic corridors. 
 
(v)  Reviewing  the  social  and  environmental  impacts  associated  with  CAREC 
regional transport development, including traffic safety, affordability, pollution, 
HIV/AIDS,  and  human  and  drug  trafficking.  The  consulting  firm  will  review 
ongoing efforts in CAREC countries in these areas and recommend measures to 
address these issues through regional transport cooperation. 
 
(vi)  Holding  country-based  meetings  with  stakeholders,  including  government 
officials,  civil  society,  nongovernment  organizations,  user  groups,  the  private 
sector, and international development partners. 
 
(vii)  Preparing  a  refined  strategy  and  implementation  action  plan  based  on  the 
transport and trade facilitation sector review and stakeholder consultation. The 
consultants will present a draft of the refined strategy and implementation action 
plan during the Transport Sector Coordinating Committee meeting in 2013 and 
finalize  the  refined  strategy  and  implementation  action  plan  based  on  the 
resulting comments. 
 
2.  International consultants will be responsible and accountable for outputs, provide advice 
on key issues to policy makers, and conduct stakeholder consultations. Under the supervision of

the  international  consultants,  the  national  consultants  will  assist  in  (i)  collecting  data  and

surveys;  (v)  providing  inputs  for  TA  reports;  and  (vi)  performing  other  tasks  as  needed.
